ENG2003 Reflection

Written by Sidney Wood

Part A – Reflection on ENG2003 Course

My overall experience in ENG2003 was both surprising and enriching. At first, I expected a traditional writing course focused on grammar and basic formatting, but instead, I encountered a dynamic, professionally relevant curriculum that emphasized clarity, audience awareness, and real-world application. The assignments pushed me to express technical information in formats that resonate with diverse audiences—from technical reports and infographics to emails and memos. Each format demanded a different style and tone, and I found myself becoming more agile and intentional with my writing choices.

One of the most useful pieces of content was the emphasis on the 7 C’s of communication. These principles became a lens through which I revised not only my assignments for this course but also my writing in other courses. I especially enjoyed the infographic presentation project. It challenged me to visualize data in ways that are engaging and digestible. The mock interviews and peer feedback exercises were also highlights, as they provided immediate, applicable insights that I will carry into my co-op applications and career. ENG2003 helped me evolve from a technically capable writer into a more strategic and audience-conscious communicator.

Part B – Reflection on Communication Development

Before ENG2003, I would have described my communication skills as serviceable but overly technical. I often defaulted to jargon-heavy explanations that made sense to me but lacked accessibility for others. Through this course, I learned to tailor my tone, structure, and vocabulary to fit different audiences, whether I was drafting an email, writing a report, or presenting in a team setting. My ability to synthesize complex information into clear, structured arguments improved significantly.

The skill I improved the most was technical writing—particularly the ability to present detailed information in a way that flows logically and maintains clarity. I learned how to properly format reports, use visuals to support my points, and craft effective executive summaries. I also became more confident in oral communication. However, I recognize that I still need to work on impromptu speaking. ENG2003 has shifted the way I approach my work in other engineering classes. I now prioritize user-centered communication, clarity in documentation, and structured collaboration. These are essential skills for future engineering practice.
